title: An Introduction to Cybernetics
summary: Ashby's 'Introduction to Cybernetics' (1956) establishes cybernetics as the science of control and communication in animals and machines. The book introduces fundamental concepts: requisite variety (a regulator must have at least as much variety as the system it regulates), the good regulator theorem (every good regulator must be a model of the system), and homeostasis (self-regulation maintaining stability). Ashby develops these ideas through rigorous mathematical treatment of state spaces, transformations, and information flow, making cybernetics applicable across biology, engineering, and social systems.
smoc_relevance_summary: Ashby's requisite variety principle directly informs SMoC's approach to observability and analysis. To analyze code (regulate its quality), analysis tools must have sufficient variety (expressive power) to match code complexity. This explains why SMoC needs 167 atoms, 33 roles, 8 dimensions—requisite variety to match real code's diversity. The good regulator theorem grounds SMoC's emphasis on models: Collider builds graph models of code because any tool that successfully regulates code quality must contain a model of that code. Documentation is literally a regulator (guides development)—by Ashby's theorem, docs must model the system. Poor docs fail as regulators because they lack requisite variety (don't capture actual complexity).

key_smoc_concepts.mapping: Ashby's law: only variety can destroy variety. A regulator must possess at least as much variety as the system being regulated. In SMoC: analysis tools must have expressive power matching code complexity. This justifies 167 atoms, 33 roles, 8 dimensions—not arbitrary proliferation but necessary variety to regulate diverse code patterns. Static analyzers with low variety (simple pattern matching) can't regulate complex emergent properties; SMoC's rich ontology provides requisite variety.
quotes_or_pages: p.207: The regulator's variety must match disturbance variety

key_smoc_concepts.mapping: Every good regulator of a system must be a model of that system. In SMoC: Collider is a regulator (assesses code quality), therefore it must model code (as graphs). Documentation regulates development, therefore must model system behavior. Comments regulate understanding, therefore must model code semantics. When regulation fails (bad docs, unmaintained comments), it's because the model diverged from reality—violating Ashby's theorem.

Ashby emphasizes that understanding a system requires observing sufficient state variables. In SMoC's triad: code text (one state), graph structure (another state), purpose/docs (third state) together provide requisite variety for complete observation. One state alone is insufficient—Ashby's principle.

gaps_or_extensions: Ashby works in general cybernetics. SMoC extends to specific software contexts and adds categorical formalism, free energy dynamics, and constructal optimization Ashby doesn't address.
